baseline_groups.claim_summary: Workers earn positive markups (surplus > 1) relative to their minimum willingness to accept (WTA), indicating they capture surplus from gig platform work.
baseline_groups.notes: Mean surplus ratio: 1.24 (p<0.001). Unweighted. N=84 survey respondents with hourly contracts.

baseline_groups.claim_summary: Workers earn positive markups relative to ex-post WTA (adjusted after job completion).
baseline_groups.notes: Mean surplus ratio: 1.16 (p<0.001). Smaller than ex-ante WTA markup.

baseline_groups.claim_summary: Workers earn positive markups relative to their outside option wage.
baseline_groups.notes: Mean surplus ratio: 1.50 (p<0.001). N=46 (fewer workers report outside wages). Largest markup.

baseline_groups.claim_summary: Workers earn positive markups on fixed-price contracts relative to ex-post WTA.
baseline_groups.notes: Mean surplus ratio: 1.87 (p<0.001). N=99 fixed-price contracts. Largest markup of all.

global_notes: Paper: 'Who Benefits from the Online Gig Economy?' by Stanton & Thomas (AER). Survey of 113 workers on a gig platform. Four surplus measures (hourly WTA, hourly ex-post, hourly outside wage, fixed-price ex-post). Many specs apply across all 4 outcomes. Balance tests compare survey participants vs non-participants. Quantile analysis shows surplus distribution. OLS predictor specs test what predicts surplus levels. IPW weights adjust for selection into survey.
